column6: Oranges are actually a type of berry! Theyâ€™re one of the most popular fruits in the world.
column7: 1-2 oranges per day provides a good dose of vitamin C, which boosts your immune system.

column6: Strawberries aren't true berries by botanical definition, they are part of the rose family.
column7: The daily fruit intake recommendation is 1.5-2cups of fruit per day. Munch on 12-16 strawberries as part of your healthy diet with this rich source of vitamin C, fibre and antioxident

column6: Pineapple is not a single fruit, but a cluster of hundreds of tiny fruitlets fused together!
column7: Eating 1-2 slices a day aids digestion and provides a good dose of vitamin C and manganese.

column6: There are over 8,000 varieties of grapes around the world! Some types have been around for over 6,000 years.
column7: A small bunch (about 1 cup) of grapes is a refreshing, heart-healthy snack full of antioxidants.

column6: Bananas are technically berries too, and they can float in water!
column7: 1-2 bananas a day helps provide potassium for muscle function and maintaining healthy blood pressure.

column6: Basketball was invented in 1891 using a soccer ball and peach baskets as hoops!
column7: Playing 30-45 minutes of basketball improves cardiovascular health, enhances coordination, and strengthens muscles.

column6: The longest tennis match lasted over 11 hours across three days at Wimbledon in 2010!
column7: A 30-60 minute tennis session can boost endurance, improve reflexes, and burn calories while toning muscles.

column6: Bowling is one of the oldest sports, dating back over 5,000 years to ancient Egypt!
column7: A 1-hour bowling session strengthens your arms, improves hand-eye coordination, and is a fun way to socialize.

column6: Volleyball was originally called "Mintonette" when it was created in 1895!
column7: Playing 30-60 minutes of volleyball enhances agility, strengthens core muscles, and boosts team collaboration skills.

column6: Football (soccer) is the most popular sport in the world, with over 250 million players in more than 200 countries!
column7: Playing football for 45-90 minutes improves cardiovascular fitness, builds endurance, and sharpens strategic thinking.
